bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, September 6, 1940

div1.p: Kean comments on Truby's manuscript about the yellow fever experiments. He complains that some "rank candidates" are lobbying to be included in the Roll of Honor.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, September 6, 1940
div1.p:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Sept. 6th 1940 My dear Truby

Your M M S of the Yellow
Fever Episode in Havana in 1900-
1901 came this morning and I
have spent the best part of the
day most agreeably in the memo
ries of forty years' ago while
reading it- I have made a
few notes in pencil in answer
to your pencil queries on the
blank sides of the pages and
have made a few unimportant
corrections and am returning it
as you may want to send it off
AC
T
2
to Dr. Hench- Your many interesting
details and the freshness of
your memory will be a great
help and joy to him, as it is to
me- I have been able to help
you out with a few dates, but
my diary is far from full &
I find I made no entries at all
for the first two weeks of Nov.
1900- I was very busy in those
days and did not take my
diary very seriously - but as my
diary has always been a factual
one intended to help out a poor
memory I have been always very
careful to get accurately what
I have recorded in it-

As to Agramonte's claims which
AC
T
3
you find unfounded, I dont
think I ever had any knowledge
and certainly have nothing which
I could put up against his claims
of having looked after the mosqui-
to work, but you have, and I am
perfectly willing to accept your memory.
I doubt however whether it is worth
while after all these years to raise
the question- I am much pleased
to have you bring to light the work
of Sergt. Neate and I know it
would please Walter Reed if the
spirits of the dead can follow the
small affairs of this world-

I remember that he came to me and
spoke as you have done of Neate's
faithful reliability and said that
he would like to get a gratuity for him
4
(You know Gen. Wood had put the fund
in my hands for disbursement.) So he
proposed that Neate should be the guinea
pig for a test if Pungens could carry
yellow fever and it was done and
he got his $100- but it did not come
within the specifications for the Roll
of Honor- By the way there are some
rank candidates now attempting to
break in on the Roll of Honor and as
they have pooled forces, and the
Military Committees are now much
occupied with great affairs, there
is some danger that they may break
in- One in the very comely widow
of Dr. Roger Post Ames who has the
backing of Senator Shepherd Chairman
of Senate Military Committee. Of course
Ames did not have experimental y. f.
or risk his life in any test and I think
5
that his subsequent behavior in trying
to establishing a record of having
yellow fever in Columbia Hospital
later, (when he probably realized that
it would be valuable) and his
experiments later with human life
in the infection of Pvt. D. L. Driscoll
Co. F. 26 Inf at Fort McIntosh when it
had no scientific value, but might put
him in the lime light, these were really
criminal acts which negative his
good work at Columbia Bks-
This poor man Driscoll is now also
an applicant for the Roll of Honor
& the accompanying pension, tho -
his case did not advance the
knowledge of the cause of yellow fever
at all: as the fact had been already
fully demonstrated- Affectionate regards
to your good wife- Mrs Ireland has just
had her gall bladder removed with a big stone in it-
& is doing very well

Cordially yours,
J. R. Kean
P. S. over
AC
T
P. S. I think that you have been
very kind and generous in the
mention of me that you make
in various places in your
fine article and I do not
want to send off your excel-
lent article without thanking
you for it.
Yrs
J. R. K
